page.title: 11The Canal, Wombourne
page.content: The Staffordshire and Worcestershire canal traverses Wombourne in a North-South direction. It was built by James Brindley between 1766 and 1772 and planned to unite the Severn and the Trent thus providing an outlet for Black Country coal. Today it has no commercial use as it is so outdated. The bridges are narrow and its lock width severely limits the size of boat, the tradional narrow boat being the largest craft to sail on the canal. The speed limit is 4 mph while the numerous locks help to reduce the effective speed still further. The summit of the canal is at Compton and it ends at Stourport on Severn where it falls 294 feet through 33 locks. Ounsdale High School use it for canoeing and have built a canoe centre on its banks.
